SILPs. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Synthesis of ILs with cations bearing sulfomethyl functionality (13, 14) and preparation of the corresponding SILPs (MTBE: tert‑butyl methyl ether). Scheme 2 Fig. 1 Oligomerisation of isobutene in the presence of SILP-5a (100 °C, 3 h). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Oligomerisation of isobutene in the presence of SILP-4b (100 °C, 3 h). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Oligomerisation of isobutene in the presence of SILP-5b (100 °C, 3 h). The catalyst was heated in vacuum between the subsequent runs for (a) 15 min or (b) 2 h. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Oligomerisation of isobutene in the presence of SILP-13 (100 °C, 3 h). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Oligomerisation of isobutene in the presence of SILP-13 (80 °C, 2 h). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Oligomerisation of isobutene in the presence of SILP-13 (80 °C, 1 h). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Oligomerisation of isobutene in the presence of SILP-14 (80 °C, 2 h). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 FT-IR spectra obtained by pyridine adsorption/desorption. Py (6 mbar) was adsorbed on 150 °C dehydrated samples at 50 °C. Left: SILP-4a (desorption at 50 °C (a), at 100 °C (b), at 150 °C (c)). Right: SILP-5a (desorption at 100 °C (a), at 200 °C (b)). (B-Py: Brønsted acid sites, L-Py: Lewis acid sites, B-L-Py: overlapping Brønsted/Lewis acid sites, Si-OH-Py: weak interactions with silanol groups.). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 FT-IR spectra obtained by pyridine adsorption/desorption. Py (6 mbar) was adsorbed on 150 °C dehydrated samples at 50 °C. Left: SILP-5b (desorption at 50 °C (a), at 100 °C (b), at 150 °C (c)). Right: SILP-5c (desorption at 50 °C (a), at 100 °C (b), at 150 °C (c)). (B-Py: Brønsted acid sites, L-Py: Lewis acid sites, B-L-Py: overlapping Brønsted/Lewis acid sites, Si-OH-Py: weak interactions with silanol groups.). Fig. 9 Fig. 10 FT-IR spectra obtained by pyridine adsorption/desorption. Py (6 mbar) was adsorbed on 150 °C dehydrated samples at 50 °C. Left: SILP-13 (desorption at 50 °C (a), at 100 °C (b), at 150 °C (c)). Right: SILP-14 (desorption at 50 °C (a), at 100 °C (b), at 150 °C (c)). (B-Py: Brønsted acid sites, L-Py: Lewis acid sites, B-L-Py: overlapping Brønsted/Lewis acid sites, Si-OH-Py: weak interactions with silanol groups.). Brønsted acidic ionic liquids with different type of cations (pyridinium, morpholinium, pyrrolidinium, imidazolium), N-sulfoalkyl chain length and different anions (triflate, hydrogensulfate and tetrafluoroborate) were prepared and immobilised on silica by adsorption. The ionic liquids were characterised by NMR and IR. Surface properties and Brønsted/Lewis acidity of the supported catalysts were also determined. Their catalytic activity and recyclability were compared in the oligomerisation of isobutene to obtain products that can be used as jet fuel blending components after hydrogenation. The results proved that imidazolium ionic liquids can be replaced by less toxic non-aromatic versions without any loss in their activity and stability. By the introduction of shorter sulfoalkyl chain into the cation, excellent results could be obtained even under milder conditions (lower temperature and shorter reaction time). Catalytic activity was shown to correlate to the Brønsted acidity of the catalyst. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Oligomerisation Catalyst recycling Non-aromatic cations Acidity Jet fuel 1 Introduction The most important blendstocks of gasolines and diesel fuels are mixtures of different carbon number isoparaffins, or high isoparaffin content fractions from the aspects of performance properties, environment protection and health. Gasoline boiling point range isoparaffins have high octane number and energy content [1], their sensibility is low, practically they are sulphur and aromatic free. They have high heat and oxidation stability (no resin and deposit formation during storage and in fuel tank, etc.), they are less toxic and the harmful material formation is lower due to their cleaner ignition [2]. Isoparaffins in the diesel fuel boiling point range have high energy content and cetane number [3], generate no particulate emission by ignition and their flow properties are good at low temperature [4]. Moreover, they are the most suitable hydrocarbons from the aspect of environment protection due to their high hydrogen content, low carbon content, and their relatively easier biodegradation and low toxicity [5]. Hyperbranched oligomers can be obtained from ethylene by chain walking technology in the presence of Ni- [6,7] or Pd-complexes [8]. Oligomerisation of lower value light hydrocarbons (from both fossil and renewable sources e.g. from fluid catalytic cracking, cracking of polymers or wastes, steam cracking of hydrocarbon mixtures, cracking and deoxygenation of biomass or from Fischer-Tropsch C3 C6 olefins) leads to different boiling point range isoolefins (e.g. gasoline, jet fuel, diesel fuel, and base oil boiling point range components can be formed depending on the level of oligomerisation), which can be transformed to isoparaffins via hydrogenation. In addition to fuels, olefin oligomers can be used as precursors to petrochemicals (e.g. production of alkyl-aromatics, alcohols, solvents, etc.) [9]. Besides transition metal catalysed reactions [10], the conversion of C3 C5 olefins to higher molecular weight products is mostly affected under acidic conditions [11]. In the industry, solid phosphoric acid catalysis has been used since the 1930s [12,13]. In order to obtain catalysts with higher stability and improved performance, several heterogeneous catalysts have been developed including supported phosphoric acid [14,15], zeolites [16] or ion exchange resins [17,18]. These catalysts have been used effectively for the selective oligomerisation of isobutene to produce dimers, trimers, etc. depending on the methodology [19]. However, there are some drawbacks regarding the utilisation of these solid acids, such as the limited lifetime, equipment corrosion, and non-regenerability of solid phosphoric acids, higher operating temperatures and pressures required by zeolites and low thermal stability of ion-exchange resins [20]. Recently, several alternative methodologies, such as the application of heteropolyacids [21] or acidic metal organic frameworks [22,23] have been reported. Due to their unique properties, e. g. non-volatility, high polarity, excellent solvation properties and great variability, ionic liquids (ILs) are widely used as solvents and/or catalysts in organic reactions. They facilitate product/catalyst separation and catalyst recycling in liquid/liquid biphasic reactions [24]. In oligomerisation they may serve as solvents in transition metal- or acid catalysed reactions [25]. Lewis- or Brønsted acidic derivatives, such as chloroaluminate ILs [26,27], and salts of cations with sulfobutyl side chains [28–30] were shown to be effective catalysts themselves. (The latter type of ILs can also be used as catalysts ensuring biphasic conditions in other reactions [31,32].) In order to avoid limitations caused by transfer processes and difficulties in their handling, ILs can be supported on solid carriers. These supported ionic liquid phases (SILPs) can be used for the immobilisation of metal catalysts used in oligomerisation [33] or may play the role of a solid acid catalyst [34]. Previously we have shown that silica-supported 1-methyl-3-sulfobutylimidazolium triflate can efficiently be used for the conversion of isobutene or C4 C5 olefin mixtures into jet-fuel boiling point range products [35–37]. Although ionic liquids are often referred to as green solvents, detailed toxicity studies have been started only in the past few years [38]. The type of the cation was found to be a key issue in the extent of toxicity, that was found to decrease on going from aromatic heterocyclic nitrogen-containing compounds (pyridinium and imidazolium) to non-aromatic cyclic and acyclic compounds (such as pyrrolidinium, ammonium, and morpholinium) [39]. Also, in comparison with other head groups (pyrrolidinium, pyridinium, piperidinium or morpholinium) the imidazolium group exhibited the lowest biodegradation potential [40]. Based on these findings, the goal of the present study was twofold. First, the efficiency of SILPs obtained from ILs with different cations bearing a sulfobutyl side chain was compared in order to substitute the original imidazolium-type SILP catalyst with a less toxic non-aromatic version. Moreover, as acidity of ILs with sulfonated side chains was shown to be dependant both on the choice of the anion and the length of the sulfoalkyl substituent [41–43], the effect of changes in the structure of the ILs was investigated to produce a catalyst showing good performance even under milder conditions. As isoparaffins, bearing good burning properties and low freezing point [44,45] and meeting all the requirements of aircraft operations, may be the most suitable components of alternative jet fuel in the future, investigations aimed at the production of branched oligomers in the boiling point range of 150 °C-270 °C. 2 Experimental The conversion and selectivity of the reactions were determined by analysing the composition of the reaction mixtures with GC equipped with a FID detector and a 30 m SPB-1 column. The assignment of the chromatographic peaks was carried out by GC–MS measurements (Shimadzu Q2010 Plus gas chromatograph, Shimadzu QP2010 SE mass spectrometer). Boiling point ranges were determined using chromatograms obtained with 1-alkene and n-alkane standards (C8 C18). NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance 400 spectrometer. The specific surface area and pore size distribution of the catalysts were determined by nitrogen adsorption/desorption measured with a Micromeritics ASAP 2000-type instrument on samples previously outgassed overnight in vacuum at the temperature of 105 °C. The surface area of the samples (S BET) was determined by the BET method. The pore size distribution was calculated from the desorption branch of the isotherms using the BJH (Barret–Joyner–Halenda) theory. Acidity of the samples was characterized by FT-IR spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine (Py). Spectra were measured on a Nicolet Compact 640 spectrometer by self-supported wafer technique. Pellets of 2 cm2 size were pressed from the samples, placed into a special IR cell with in situ heat treatment facility, heated up to 150 °C in high vacuum (10−6 mbar) with a rate of 10 °C/min and dehydrated for 1 h. Following 30 min contact with Py (6 mbar) at 50 °C, the sample was evacuated subsequently at 50, 100, 150 and 200 °C, for 30 min. After each evacuation step a spectrum was recorded at IR beam temperature with a resolution of 2 cm−1. The spectra were normalized to 5 mg/cm2wt of the wafers for comparison. IR (KBr): 1479, 1259, 1173, 1031 cm−1. 2.5 Preparation of the catalysts Silica gel (Kieselgel 60 (0.35–0.70 μm), Merck) was pre-treated by heating for 5 h at 250 °C in vacuum. Then it was allowed to cool to room temperature in a desiccator and was stored under argon. A mixture of silica gel (1 g), ionic liquid (4a,b, 5a-c, 6a, 13 or 14) (1 mmol) and 2.5 ml MeOH was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. MeOH was removed in vacuum and the catalyst was dried at 100 °C in vacuum for 5 h to produce the supported ionic liquid. 2.6 Oligomerisation experiments The reactions were carried out in an autoclave under argon. The autoclave was cooled to −15 °C and 6 ml isobutene was charged into the reactor, which contained the catalyst prepared according to Section 2.5. The autoclave was pressurised with argon (30 bar, room temperature). The mixture was stirred at 80–100 °C for 1–4 h. The autoclave was cooled to −15 °C, the organic phase was separated and analysed by gas chromatography. The SILP catalyst was washed with pentane (3 × 5 ml), dried in vacuum at 100 °C for 15 min (SILP-4a — SILP-6a, SILP-5a and SILP-5b) or 2 h (SILP-5b, SILP-13 and SILP-14) and reused. 3 Results 3.1 Preparation of ionic liquids and SILP catalysts Brønsted acidic ionic liquids with pyridinium- (4a, 4b), morpholinium- (5a-5c) and pyrrolidinium cations (6a) and different anions were prepared by the reaction of the corresponding acids with the betaines (1–3) obtained by the alkylation of pyridine, pyrrolidine and morpholine, respectively (Scheme 1 ). As lower Hammett acidity functions were measured for 1-methyl-3-sulfoalkyl ILs with shorter sulfoalkyl chains [43], imidazolium and morpholinium ILs with sulfomethyl substituents (13a and 14a) were synthesised in a three-step reaction (Scheme 2 ) in order to enhance the acidity of the catalysts,. First, N-methylimidazole and N-methylmorpholine were reacted with bromochloromethane. The resulting mixtures, containing some dicationic derivatives (8 and 10) beside the main products 7 and 9, respectively, were used without further purification in the next step, a nucleophilic substitution of the chloro compounds 7 and 9 with Na2SO3 Betaines 11 and 12 were purified by recrystallisation from hot methanol to separate the products from the dicationic derivatives 8, 10. Then, they were converted to the acidic ILs 13 and 14 by the addition of an equimolar amount of trifluoromethanesulfonic acid. SILP catalysts were prepared by the adsorption of the ILs on silica. 3.2 Oligomerisation of isobutene First, the efficiencies of SILPs obtained from ILs composed of trifluoromethanesulfonate anion and different cations (SILP-4a—SILP-6a) were compared in three-hour-long reactions at 100 °C. The reaction conditions were selected based on the results of our former experiments [35]. Conversions of isobutene greater than 99% could be achieved in the presence of each catalyst and all of them showed stable performance throughout at least eight subsequent runs. The main products were the trimers obtained in 56–70% yields and the ratio of the C12+C16 fractions was between 85 and 91% in all of the experiments (As an example, Fig. 1 shows the results obtained with SILP-5a, data of experiments carried out with the other two catalysts are included in the Supporting information, Figures S1 and S2). Next, oligomerisation of isobutene was carried out with supported catalysts (SILP-4b and SILP-5b) prepared from two ionic liquids with hydrogensulfate anions. Although good conversion could be achieved with the fresh catalysts, the shift of product distribution towards dimers shows the lower activity of these SILPs (Figs. 2 and 3 a) compared to SILP-4a — SILP-6a. Moreover, a marked loss of effectiveness was observed when the catalysts were reused. In contrast, only a slight increase of dimers together with a somewhat lower ratio of C20+ products could be noticed when oligomerisation was performed with catalysts with trifluoromethansulfonate anions (SILP-4a — SILP-6a, Fig. 1 and Figures S1 and S2). When SILP-5b bearing adsorbed 1-(4-sulfobutyl)morpholinium hydrogensulfate (5b) was heated in vacuum for a longer time (2 h instead of 15 min) before reuse, it showed somewhat slower deactivation. However, the pronounced increase in the ratio of dimeric products even in the second run indicated the lower activity that resulted in a progressive decrease in the conversion of the substrate from the third run on. No oligomer products were detected under the same conditions using supported 1-(4-sulfobutyl)morpholinium tetrafluoroborate (SILP-5c). (It should be mentioned that oligomerisation in the presence of a catalyst obtained by depositing sulfuric acid and [BMIM][BF4] on silica led similar results to those obtained with catalysts SILP4a—SILP-6a under the standard conditions (100 °C, 3 h) (Figure S3). The ratio of trimers were approximately the same, but a higher and slightly increasing dimer selectivity was observed.) As an enhanced acidity of imidazolium ILs with shorter sulfoalkyl chains was reported by Dyson et al. [43], oligomerisation was performed with SILP-13 under the standard conditions (100 °C, 3 h). Gas chromatographic and GC–MS analysis of the product revealed the formation of a more complex mixture than before (Figure S4). In addition to the awaited oligomerisation products, formation of C9 C10, C13 C15 and C17 C18 alkenes could also be detected. Moreover, a greater variety of oligomer products could be distinguished than in the mixture obtained with SILPs with cations bearing sulfobutyl groups (eg. with SILP-5a, Figure S5). This can be explained by cracking and isomerisation processes due to the higher acidity of IL 13. 13C NMR and DEPT investigations of the product mixture obtained with SILP-5a made it possible to assign most of the carbon signals of the main products (Figures S6-S9) [47]. Although the peaks corresponding to dimer A and trimers B, C could easily be distinguished in the oligomerisation product obtained with SILP-13, their intensity decreased compared to other signals. At the same time, signals assigned to tetramers D-F disappeared, in spite of the presence of chromatographic peaks in the tetramer region. New signals appeared with chemical shifts corresponding to olefinic (Figure S7) and methyl carbons (Figure S9) together with the lack of methylene carbons of tetramers (Figure S8). All these observations support the assumption that an isomerisation process accompanies oligomerisation. At the same time, catalyst SILP-13 showed a stable performance and exerted excellent selectivity towards products in the boiling point range of 150 °C-270 °C (Fig. 4 ). Only a slight decrease of activity is indicated by a small rise in the amount of low-boiling point products at the expense of C20+oligomers. It should be mentioned that a two-hour-long heating of this catalyst was found to be necessary before reuse to achieve good results. Catalyst SILP-13 was proved to be efficient even at 80 °C. Ratio of products formed in cracking processes decreased, especially in shorter reactions. After optimisation of the reaction time (Figure S10), stability tests were carried out in two-hour-long (Fig. 5 ) and one-hour-long reactions (Fig. 6 ). Products with boiling points between 150 °C-270 °C were obtained with selectivities around 90% in two-hour-long reactions. Results of shorter reactions were found to be less reproducible, probably because even small differences in heat transfer from the oil bath through the wall of the autoclave might have significant effects on the outcome of the oligomerisation process. A further decrease in the reaction temperature to 60 °C led to a marked drop in the conversion to 46–48% (3 h). Under these conditions the dimers were obtained with excellent selectivity (88–92%). In accordance with the other goal to use SILP phases obtained with less toxic ILs, the efficiency of SILP-14 bearing a morpholinium cation was tested under the optimal conditions mentioned above (80 °C, 2 h, Fig. 7 ). Similarly to the observations gathered in the reactions catalysed with different SILPs bearing cations with sulfobutyl chains, it can be concluded that the change in the type of the cation has no considerable effect on the performance in case of catalysts prepared from ILs of higher acidity either. 3.3 Characterisation of SILP phases The specific surface area (SBET) and pore volume of the catalysts and the original silica support (Table 1 ) were determined from the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms (Figures S11, S12). All the samples exhibit type IV isotherms [48], with hysteresis loops of type H2, which is an indication of mesopores of not well defined shape with narrow necks and wide bodies [49]. The silica support has mesopores, mainly in the 2–10 nm region (Figure S13) and has no measurable micropore surface area. As it can be expected, its impregnation with ionic liquids results in decreased BET surface. It can be assumed that although the total pore volume values decreases because an active IL film is formed on the wall of the pores and/or the IL blocks some of the pores of the support, the pores retain their shape during the preparation process. Probably due to the lower molecular mass of ILs used for the preparation of SILP-13 and SILP 14, the change in the surface properties is smaller for the latter phases (Figure S14). Although some further loss of BET surface and pore volume, probably due to coke formation, can be observed in the case of spent catalyst, the deviation from the original value is not significant. Surface acid sites were determined by the FT-IR spectroscopic analysis of adsorbed pyridine. Bands appearing at 1545–1550 cm−1, 1635–1640 cm−1 and 1610–1620 can be attributed to the ν19b and ν8a and ν8b vibrations of the pyridinium ring, respectively, formed via protonation of pyridine on Brønsted acid sites (B-Py). Peaks in the regions of 1440–1470 cm−1 and 1610–1630 cm−1 can be assigned to the ν19b and ν8a vibrations of pyridine coordinated to Lewis acid sites (L-Py), respectively. The absorption around 1490 cm−1, corresponding to vibration ν19a, is not specific as it is the result of overlapping signals of pyridine both on Brønsted and Lewis acid sites (B-L-Py). Absorbances at 1447 cm−1 and 1598 cm−1 indicate the formation of weak hydrogen bonds between pyridine and surface silanol (Si-OH-Py) groups. While pyridine adsorption bands give information about the type of acidity, the temperature of desorption is related to the acid strength of the solid. SILP-4a and SILP-5a showed similar behaviour revealing bands typical for Brønsted acid sites (Fig. 8 ). Complete desorption of pyridine was observed at 150 °C and above. In contrast, adsorbed pyridine could be detected even at 150 °C in the spectra of SILP-5b and SILP-5c (Fig. 9 ) At the same time, peaks corresponding to both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites can be traced in the spectra of the SILP phase prepared from the IL with hydrogensulfate anion (SILP-5b), whereas the measurements revealed strong Lewis acid sites but no Brønsted acidity in the sample with tetrafluoroborate anion (SILP-5c). Similarly to the other catalysts with trifluoromethanesulfonate anions, only bands corresponding to protonated pyridine could be distinguished in the spectra of SILP-13 and SILP-14 (Fig. 10 ). At the same time, stronger acidity compared to SILP-4a or SILP-5a (Fig. 8) is indicated by the presence of adsorbed pyridine even at 150 °C (Fig. 10). 4 Discussion According to literature examples, catalytic activity and Hammett acidity of ILs depends both on the chain length of the cation and the choice of the anion. Hammett acidity function of SO3H-functionalized imidazolium ILs was shown to decrease together with the shortening of the sulfoalkyl side chain [43]. Acidity of methyl-sulfobutylimidazolium ILs with different anions was found to change in the order TfO−>BF4 −>HSO4 − [43]. Catalytic activity of ILs with TfO− or HSO4 − anions reflected these differences e.g. in ester hydrolysis [41], esterification [42] and oligomerisation reactions [30]. At the same time, catalytic activity of methyl-sulfobutylimidazolium ILs followed the order of TfO−> HSO4 −> BF4 − in the dehydration reaction of cyclohexanol [43]. Better performance of the IL with HSO4 − anion than that with BF4 − ion was attributed to the dehydration power and the poor nucleophilicity of the former ion. The same trends can be noticed on comparing the efficiency of supported catalysts investigated in the present work (Table 2 ), such as better performance of SILP-4a (entry 1) and SILP-5a (entry 4) than that of SILP-4b (entry 2) or SILP-5b (entry 5), as well as higher activity of ILs with cations with sulfomethyl chains SILP-13 and SILP-14 (entries 9–12). The latter statement can be demonstrated by the shift of selectivity towards heavier products at higher temperature (entry 9), or by the increase in TOF values in reactions with similar selectivity (entries 10–12) as before (entry 1). However, the difference between ILs with HSO4 − and BF4 − anions is more pronounced than in the work of Dyson [43], as no detectable isobutene conversion could be obtained with SILP-5c. The catalytic data are in accordance with the results of FT-IR investigations of acidity. The inactivity of SILP-5c can be explained by the lack of Brønsted acid sites (Fig. 9) in the supported ionic liquid. Beside Brønsted acidity, a considerable amount of Lewis acid sites was observed in the spectra (Fig. 9) of the catalyst with HSO4 − ions (SILP-5b) while only Brønsted acid sites were present in the spectra of SILPs with triflate ions. Also, higher acidity (Fig. 10) and as a consequence, higher catalytic activity (Figs. 4-7) were observed for supported sulfomethyl ILs (SILP-13 and SILP-14). It should be mentioned that all the catalysts prepared form ILs with TfO− anions showed good stability upon reuse, irrespective of the choice of the type of the cation (Figs. 1, S1 and S2), or the length of the sulfoalkyl chain (Figs. 4-7). 5 Conclusions Supported Brønsted acidic imidazolium ionic liquids can be substituted with equally effective SILPs bearing less toxic non-aromatic cations. The use of ILs with sulfomethyl side chains instead of the usual sulfobutyl moiety makes it possible to carry out oligomerisation under milder conditions. SILPs of different structure were found to be efficient catalysts in the oligomerisation of isobutene to produce branched alkenes that can be used as blending components for jet fuel after hydrogenation. By the proper choice of reaction conditions, high selectivity could be achieved towards products in the boiling point range of 150 °C—270 °C with SILPs obtained from ILs with trifluromethanesulfonate anion (SILP-4a, SILP-5a, SILP-6a, SILP-13 and SILP-14). Higher acidity of ILs with aromatic and non-aromatic cations bearing sulfomethyl moiety was reflected by their higher catalytic activity leading to similarly excellent results at lower temperature and shorter reaction time. Catalysts SILP-4b and SILP-5b incorporating HSO4 − anions were less active, moreover, their stability was much lower which hinders efficient recycling. Also, these catalysts were found to be extremely sensitive to the presence of traces of water. The differences in the catalytic activity of the tested SILPs corresponded well to the FTIR data of pyridine adsorption/desorption experiments. The inactivity of SILP-5c bearing BF4 − anions can probably be explained by the lack of Brønsted acid sites in this catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Brønsted acidic ionic liquids with different type of cations (pyridinium, morpholinium, pyrrolidinium, imidazolium), N-sulfoalkyl chain length and different anions (triflate, hydrogensulfate and tetrafluoroborate) were prepared and immobilised on silica by adsorption. The ionic liquids were characterised by NMR and IR. Surface properties and Brønsted/Lewis acidity of the supported catalysts were also determined. Their catalytic activity and recyclability were compared in the oligomerisation of isobutene to obtain products that can be used as jet fuel blending components after hydrogenation. The results proved that imidazolium ionic liquids can be replaced by less toxic non-aromatic versions without any loss in their activity and stability. By the introduction of shorter sulfoalkyl chain into the cation, excellent results could be obtained even under milder conditions (lower temperature and shorter reaction time). Catalytic activity was shown to correlate to the Brønsted acidity of the catalyst.

coredata.dc:title: Recyclable supported Brønsted acidic ionic liquid catalysts with non-aromatic cations for the oligomerization of isobutene under mild conditions
